text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Education
Daily Report -- A new study on Education - Pharmaceutical Education is now
available. According to news reporting out of Detroit, Michigan, by NewsRx
editors, research stated, "Elective courses are required in Doctor of Pharmacy
(PharmD) curricula in the United States, but they may receive less attention
than required courses in the core curriculum. Elective courses can serve as a
platform for innovation in, experimentation with, and implementation of high-
impact educational practices."

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Wayne State
University, "However, these benefits may not always be realized or maximized.
We advocate for an 'elective curriculum' that is strategically designed and
intentionally planned and managed. Students, faculty members, and
administrators all play important roles in creating this curriculum."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "To ensure the
curriculum is vibrant and thriving, attention is needed to: alignment with
institutional missions, meeting the postgraduation needs of students and
employers, enhancing faculty development and faculty experience, strengthening
partnerships within the university and/or external entities, and moving the
profession forward."

For more information on this research see: Cultivating a Vibrant and Thriving
Elective Curriculum In Pharmacy Schools. _American Journal of Pharmaceutical
Education_ , 2020;84(4):410-414. _American Journal of Pharmaceutical
Education_ can be contacted at: Amer Assoc Coll Pharmacy, 1426 Prince Street,
Alexandria, VA 22314-2815, USA.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting C.L. Garwood, Wayne State University, College of Pharmacy and
Health Sciences, 259 Mack Ave, Ste 2190, Detroit, MI 48201, United States.
Additional authors for this research include H.D. Berlie and K.K. Janke.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.5688/ajpe7802>. This DOI is a link to an online electronic
document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source
for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Findings from Wayne State University in the Area of Pharmaceutical Education Described (Cultivating a Vibrant and Thriving Elective Curriculum In Pharmacy Schools): Education - Pharmaceutical Education
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Education Daily Report -- A new study on Education - Pharmaceutical Education is now available. According to news reporting out of Detroit, Michigan, by NewsRx editors, research stated, “Elective courses are required in Doctor of Pharmacy (PharmD) curricula in the United States, but they may receive less attention than required courses in the core curriculum. Elective courses can serve as a platform for innovation in, experimentation with, and implementation of high-impact educational practices.”

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Wayne State University, “However, these benefits may not always be realized or maximized. We advocate for an ‘elective curriculum’ that is strategically designed and intentionally planned and managed. Students, faculty members, and administrators all play important roles in creating this curriculum.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “To ensure the curriculum is vibrant and thriving, attention is needed to: alignment with institutional missions, meeting the postgraduation needs of students and employers, enhancing faculty development and faculty experience, strengthening partnerships within the university and/or external entities, and moving the profession forward.”

For more information on this research see: Cultivating a Vibrant and Thriving Elective Curriculum In Pharmacy Schools. American Journal of Pharmaceutical Education, 2020;84(4):410-414. American Journal of Pharmaceutical Education can be contacted at: Amer Assoc Coll Pharmacy, 1426 Prince Street, Alexandria, VA 22314-2815, USA.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting C.L. Garwood, Wayne State University, College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences, 259 Mack Ave, Ste 2190, Detroit, MI 48201, United States. Additional authors for this research include H.D. Berlie and K.K. Janke.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.5688/ajpe7802. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
